div1.p: Frost describes the pace of his editing work on Henry Rose Carter's manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Laura Armistead Carter, July 13, 1927
div1.opener:
Frost - re Book text for
Section III: Part 2
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
615 NORTH WOLFE STREET
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
BALTIMORE, MD.
July 13, 1927.
Miss Laura A. Carter,
Dunlora, Box 453,
Charlottesville, Virginia.
My dear Miss Laura:
div1.p:
Mrs. Smiley is getting along excellently with
the manuscript, having now finished the copying of
sections I and II, and part I of section III. In
addition to that she and I together have checked
your index of bibliographic references in sections I
and II and believe that as an index this is now com-
plete, though of course a good many of the references
remain to be filled in in proper form and verified.

With reference to section III, part II, we
are in some doubt as to what text to use for making
the copy. I find in the files two texts, namely:

(1) aA loose, that is, unbound manuscript of
your own typing, with amendments in your father's
handwriting and with notes which you have transcribed &
inserted here and there, either by pinning on slips
or by pasting them in. This, I presume, is athe copy
which you intended thus to use, and my only doubt
arises from the fact that it was tied up in a bundle
with a similar manuscript of section III, part I,
on which there was your notation not to use this
manuscript but another more completely revised one
which we have found (for part 1)

(2) the bound copy made in the offices of
the International Health Board. This, so far as I
have checked it, seems to be identical with your
own copy and to have had incorporated in it all the
revisions which are indicated in your copy.

I assume that in making our copy, we should
use the one which I have indicated under (1) above
and am writing to you merely to confirm this.

As Mrs. Smiley will be able to complete
the copying well before the end of the month I think
it may be advantageous for her thereafter to make an
index of references and allusions for section III
similar to what you have already made for section I
and II. I think something of this kind, bringing
together in one place all the references to and quo-
tations from each authority, will be necessary; and
with the guidance afforded by your index of the
other sections I think that Mrs. Smiley can make this
index quite satisfactorily.

As regards sections I and II, which I have
already been over carefully, I find that they need
almost no editorial revision - at least in my judgment -
and that practically nothing remains to be done on them
except to identify and verify the bibliographic
references. This will be somewhat laborious but
for the most part I think it will not be very difficult
if one works in a more complete library than we have
here.

As regards verification of all the citations
and quotations in section III where the references are
mostly to old works, this can be done only by some
one like yourself who is thoroughly familiar with
the languages in which they are written. I do not
know, in fact, that a check of all the quotations is
really necessary, because I think it is evident from
the way in which the quotations are given that your
father copied them verbatim as he read the texts
and that they were certainly done with great care
so that there is hardly any chance for an error
except a typographical one or a slip of the pen which
one ought to be able to identify from the text. I
think it is certain that in making these quotations
your father took full notes, copying from the texts,
and if these notes can eventually be found, they
may be of considerable help.

Since I have been checking over the manuscript
I have appreciated more fully than I had heretofore,
the extent and the difficulties of the work that you
have already done in putting in the notes and in
making such careful cross references as you have

Please let me know at your convenience about
the copy to be used for section III, part II. For
the rest there is nothing in this letter that re-
Miss Carter
-3-
quires any answer and certainly nothing for you
to trouble yourself about. Everything goes well and
I am confident that after you come back, after a good
rest, you will find no great difficulty in finishing
up what remains to be done, which is not a great deal.
div1.closer:
With best regards,
Very truly yours, W. H. F. WHF:F
